Every once in a while, I come across a book that shapes my thinking about a topic. I know this happens because I have a terrible memory for the mundane - and when I _do_ remember something, it's typically significant. To me, at least.

The Righteous Mind was the first significant, memorable book for me in 2018. Like most people my age, I've encountered a fair share of discussions on cognitive biases (rarely), morality (a few) and politics (far too many) but it's not often that I hear about a framework that helps me look at the discussion fundamentally differently. I think I felt strong because the primary thesis of the book (the morality framework) brought many familiar, yet nebulous, ideas within a common umbrella. And in explaining his thesis, Jonathan Haidt shared interesting explanations of many other phenomenon I've come across. Anyway, as always, ideas I found interesting:

- The idea of the Elephant and the Rider. How humans typically have an intuitive, guttural reaction to ideas, which typically reveals their value system, and then try and to come up with explanations for these reactions (e.g., brother & sister having protected sex)
- The ethics of Autonomy (freedom, choice etc), Community (duty, hierarchy, reputation etc) and Divinity (sanctity, purity etc)
- The framework of Care, Fairness, Loyalty, Authority and Liberty - and how each of these ideas developed as a function of Evolutionary Pyschology (and how group traits transfer across generations)
- The Hive Switch (humans are 20% bees) and how to turn it on - increase similarities, generate synchrony
- How religion is like an Operating System of Values that are inherited - and how societies without Religion need to continuously develop moral solutions to things
- Conservatism: The difference b/w Conservatism and Orthodoxy (defining thesis to make society "happy" v/s preserving an order), the idea of Moral Capital (that Conservatives try to prefer)
- The need for social cohesion - the experiments around how very ethnically diverse societies cause people to retreat into a version of individualism)

- And finally, when you meet someone with a different set of morals, first establish some commonality (find their elephant...), before trying to persuade (...fighting with their rider)

As I said, mind altering.

title: Annihilation of Caste
author: B.R. Ambedkar
review:
I should have read this book a long time ago. Although I disagree with a lot of what Arundhati Roy has to say, her introduction sets the stage for Ambedkar well.

Few of the (many) things I found interesting:

On Caste
- Loved Ambedkar’s definition of caste in Hinduism: “Caste is like a multistoried building with no exit and no staircase. You live and die in the same floor you were born into"
- I’d read articles about how Gandhi was a lot more complex than his traditional image, but Arundhati Roy’s story of his conflicting views on caste and case was the first time I’ve read a lot of these views. Not sure how much of it is her opinion and how much is fact - hope it's opinion.
- Political institutions should be influenced by existing societal structures. India might have needed a structure similar to what the Romans had (separate consuls and electorates for Plebs and Patricians etc.), given its stratification of caste.
- Socialism is built on the idea that the only form of power is through property. But religious and caste also defines power in society. For ex, the Oracle of Delphi ultimately approved/rejected who should be the plebeian consul in Rome, irrespective of the outcome of the election
- Grouping in society is not uncommon and isn't necessarily bad. The strength of a society, however, depends on the presence of points of contact - "organic filaments". There isn't an integrating force in caste in Hinduism

On Reform
- Inter caste marriages is a powerful driver of change, something that is become more pronounced in Indian cities today. "Fusion of blood can alone create the feeling of kith and kin"
- The real solution is to dismantle Hinduism. Hinduism is a set of rules, not principles, so it is difficult to find alternate, more progressive, interpretations.
+ The idea that priesthood becomes a profession, like law and medicine. That it shouldn’t be hereditary or birth based. Priests should be a servant of the state and should be regulated by law

I disagreed with some parts (professionalizing priesthood, for instance) but, if nothing else, Ambedkar's last idea sets the foundation for larger reform: Hindus should reflect if they are willing to let their religion change and transform or if they want it to remain the way it’s always been historically.

title: The Evolution of Beauty: How Darwin's Forgotten Theory of Mate Choice Shapes the Animal World—And Us
author: Richard O. Prum
review:
Amazing guy and captivating book. Discovered Richard Prum's work through his episode on Conversations w Tyler. The last 5 minutes of the episode -- where Prum describes the uniqueness of his vantage point by intensely focusing on topics _he_ finds appealing without being influenced by prevailing ideas of what the community believes is important -- was powerful. On a personal level for my work, should try and not be influenced too much by what others think is "important".

Some of the things I found striking:
- The idea that sexual/aesthetic selection is/was so controversial in evolutionary biology and how the community is grappling with competing hypotheses to explain the diversity of beauty. A variation of this tension keeps coming in other academic ideaspaces (e.g., the Zucman-Summers debates on income/wealth inequality) - it's interesting to see what needs to happen for the community to finally consider a fringe idea mainstream, it seems to be as much a process revolving around egos and packaging as it is about the ideas themselves
- I LOVE reading about people who are obsessed about specific ideas, and there's something about obsessing on something "narrow" in the natural world that's particularly attractive (similar reads recently: Owls of the Eastern Ice, Under Land, The OverStory). Wonder what it is about these stories that are appealing to me...
- Reading about what some of these birds do was fascinating also - duck sex (and the sexual arms race between males and females), Manakins' lek displays (and aesthetic radiation), Argus Pheasants and their plumage, the Bowerbirds' bowers etc. Should do a trip to see some of these species
- The idea that female mate choice might be a powerful evolutionary force and Prum's hypothesis that it isn't coincidental that this idea has become more in vogue at the same time the feminist movement became more mainstream
- The last part about taking the evolutionary view of beauty and applying it to the arts - who gets to define what art is? Is traditional human art also a coevolutionary process where display and desire co-evolve? Do artists shape aesthetic preferences or vice versa?

Cool book

title: The Gene: An Intimate History
author: Siddhartha Mukherjee
review:
At the risk of sounding repetitive, this was a stunning book - Siddhartha Mukherjee is a beautiful writer. As I was telling a friend, if a scientific historian can make slow, methodical scientific research as engaging as a Frederick Forsyth novel, he’s doing his job right. It’s a must read for anyone with even a passing interest in Biology

Couple of things I liked:

- Competitive scientific research makes for great reading - especially Crick-Watson v/s Wilkins v/s Franklin (on the structure of DNA), Craig Venter/Celera v/s the HGP (on sequencing the human genome) and Genentech v/s Walter Gilbert (on synthetic insulin). The academia v/s industry theme in research/innovation played out again (I last saw it in The Innovators — Bell Labs v/s Stanford/MIT)

- The chapter on the Asilomar conference was fascinating - it always amazes me when a group can self-regulate against long-term loss at the cost of immediate progress. Especially relevant today, given Junjiu Huang’s and the Chinese’s recent experiments

- I loved the ethical questions Mukherjee raises. The interesting thing about scientific innovation is that substantial innovation comes into conflict with legislation (e.g., Uber v/s Governments), but fundamental innovation comes into conflict with society’s understanding of morality and ethics. Who defines which genetic interventions may be permitted or constrained? Is it okay for a parent to abort a foetus that would have average IQ (assuming this is possible etc.)?

- The parts on Nature v/s Nurture - something I’ve always been curious about. It seems clear that, like it or not, genes play a significant part in defining who we are. The search for the gene determining sexuality was interesting as well - I wonder if we’ll find it soon, and what the political consequences might be if we knew sexuality was completely genetic

And so much more.

Reading about Genetics sometimes amuses me by how easily we use the word ‘disrupt’. “Disrupting" the home service aggregator space is fundamentally different from “disrupting” our ability to edit genomes. I wish I read more about topics like the latter.

title: Midnight's Furies: The Deadly Legacy of India's Partition
author: Nisid Hajari
review:
Loved the book. Five-stars primarily because it's so hard to find even-handed historical summaries of events in modern India. I'd naturally read about the Partition before (most recently with Indian Summer, another fantastic book), but this book brought out many nuances I'd glossed over in the past. Three things I found interesting:

1 - It reinforced my belief that Partition could have gone down a *very* different path if it was anyone but Nehru, Jinnah and Mountbatten negotiating. Each man's biases, insecurities and ambitions are critical aspects to why the subcontinent looks the way it does today.

2 - Kashmir is particularly complex. This might just be me, but I've always found it hard to find facts around what the issue is. My gripe with Indian literature is that we don't have too many respected historians writing about recent events - leading to everyone getting their version of Reality. I like how Hajari goes through the entire story, and calls out specific points where the Indian and Pakistani versions vary. Exceptionally helpful to serve as a starting point to understand Kashmir better. Must read more.

3 - I love reading about Nehru. The man had his flaws - arguably too emotional, not as tough a negotiator as Patel would have been, idealistic to a fault etc. That said, Nehru was India's embodiment of Plato's Philosopher King. As I complain to friends, every time I read about Obama's view of history and America's place in it and the challenges America faces today, I feel sad that we don't have many politicians who don't (and in many cases, can't) similarly discuss with the idea of India. Being a student of history gives you the maturity and humility to understand the underpinnings of why people, society and countries behave in a certain way today. Nehru was a rare, idealistic visionary who saw the world this way. And cobbled together a nation in a complex, difficult time. It is perhaps too soon (it has only been 50 years since he died, after all) for those who disagree with Nehru to still respect his immense, unparalleled contribution to the founding of the country. I wonder when that day will come.

title: The Dawn of Everything: A New History of Humanity
author: David Graeber
review:
DNF at ~40%. I may be the outlier here but think this was obtusely written and I had spend a lot more time than I'd like following the plot and connecting examples and vignettes to the broader theme of a certain chapter. Dare say this for most people (like me) this could have been a longform essay.

Not to overshadow the main point -- the ideas in this book are profound and so non-mainstream, it was illuminating. Some ideas:

- The idea that so much of what Rousseau/Hobbes et al claimed as the origin of human society was not based any version of archaeological evidence, and was simply a narrative device. The idea that there was wide variety and inventiveness in political structures in pre-industrial society. The framing from ‘Where did inequality come from?’ to ‘Why are we stuck in our current political structure with its associated inequality?’

- The focus on the indigenous critique (got a kick everytime he referred to indigenous American Indians as Americans). The fact that the European Enlightenment was likely sparked by exposure to indigenous tribes of North America.

- The assumption that urbanization and aggregation of humans in large, complex cities necessitates hierarchical structures. Examples from Uruk, Indus Valley etc.

- The claim that our present-day problems of inequity (politically, economically) arise because of specific systems and ideologies we have chosen to organize around rather than something inherent in human nature. The claim that it's false that we are, in today's capitalist democratic world, more free than how most humans lived in pre-industrial societies.

Overall, for someone who's read Pinker and Harari, I'm glad I read this book, fun to see two anthropology/archaeology scholars who are also anarchists describe human political history.

title: No god but God: The Origins, Evolution and Future of Islam
author: Reza Aslan
review:
5 stars because this is the first book that gave me enough context about a topic I've tried to understand for such a long time. My difficulty is that I know little enough about the that I'm unclear if Reza Aslan's interpretation of Islamic history is a subjective narrative - but I'm going to assume it's a fair, if not complete, description.

Ideas I found interesting:

- The Constitution of Medina and the fairly pluralistic, tolerant, liberal (on human rights at least) origins of Islam. The story of Muhammad is perfect content for a great TV show. The story of Muhammad in Mecca and Medina is eerily similar to the Game of Thrones sub-plot of how Daenerys freed the slaves and became their God-like prophet-ruler
- The similarities between mythologies from different religions. The story of Muhammad, Aisha and Safwan sounds similar to the story of Rama, Sita and her time in Lanka. It's interesting how the values of a man seemed to revolve on their forgiveness of their wife's alleged impropriety
- The difference between Shiiism and Sunnism (details of their respective narratives)
- The role of religion in society and how Islam was deemed to be a way of life, and not just religious faith
- The present reformation in Islam, how it is different and similar to the Reformation in Christiniaty (not having a Caliphate/Papal role, role of social media - IslamOnline.com etc)
- The religious history of the Middle East: Authoritarianism in Saudi Arabia and Wahhabism, the Houthis in Yemen, the Ayatollah in Iran
- Does democracy need secularism? Can you have a pluralistic religion-based democracy? Are we relying too much on the American experience? How does secularization (how the State eats into the role of the Church)?

title: These Precious Days: Essays
author: Ann Patchett
review:
Beautiful book. Read The Dutch House 2 years ago and loved her prose, decided to check this out...

Most of the essays were good, some were okay, some were incredible. I think I fell in love with her by the end of it -- she seems like a fun, interesting and reflective person -- and these essays make she's a close friend sharing her inner life with you.

Some fragments I liked:

- The essay "These Precious Days" with Sooki, what a moving story. Friendships work in mysterious ways. If nothing else, just read that essay.

- The essay on her friend Tavia. What a fun, inspiring story -- "At every turn, happiness was her decision."

- On how she stopped buying things for a year: "The things we buy and buy and buy are like a thick coat of Vaseline smeared on glass: we can see some shapes out there, light and dark, but in our constant craving for what we may still want, we miss too many of life’s details. It’s not as if I kept a ledger and took the money I didn’t spend on perfume and gave that money to the poor, but I came to a better understanding of money as something we earn and spend and save for the things we want and need."

- 100% agree, this is a superpower: "It turns out that having a hard wall to hit your tennis balls against is what gives them bounce. Having someone who believed in my failure more than my success kept me alert. It made me fierce. Without ever meaning to, my father taught me at a very early age to give up on the idea of approval. I wish I could bottle that freedom now and give it to every young writer I meet, with an extra bottle for the women. I would give them the ability both to love and not to care."

title: Empire of Pain: The Secret History of the Sackler Dynasty
author: Patrick Radden Keefe
review:
What a book - PRK is one of the finest writers and biographers of our generation. I liked this even more than Say Nothing and thought it was a more riveting story than Winds of Change. Part I was an engaging rags-to-riches story (honestly read like an old Jeffrey Archer novel). The details of Arthur Sackler's view of philanthropy felt new. Philanthropy really is a financial transaction and we should see it as such.

I _thought_ Part II really makes you see how unscrupulous the family was, but Part III was outrageous. Everything from a wilful disregard to what was happening on-ground to their ability to game the legal system to protect themselves (Mary Jo White! Why would you do this?!). I spent some time in school studying bankruptcies so found the last ~100 or so pages revealing about how bankruptcy law, which prizes preservation of assets and efficiency, often ignores what is "just", especially in cases where there's public interest at stake.

Anyway - I was wondering what I liked about PRK's writing. I think it's that he's extremely careful while making assertions and avoids making broad generalizations without sufficient evidence. Instead, he spends so much time developing the detail and the specifics of a situation -- and this si important -- makes general observations from there. It feels much more compelling and honest. I started reading the new Walter Isaacson book right after this and felt like reading an amateur biography in comparison (he has BS lines like "She was an outsider in high school. And that's something *all* creative people share." Might be true, but come on!)

Highly recommend! And hope the Sacklers get what they deserve.

title: When We Cease to Understand the World
author: Benjamín Labatut
review:
First book of the year and I loved it. The most genre bending book I've come across in recent memory, still unsure if this was non-fiction or a novel. I'm not even sure it matters -- reminds me of Teju Cole's argument that these divisions are arbitrary, almost naive assertions of what is true and what is not (the interview's great: https://bombmagazine.org/articles/teju-cole/)

In any case, loved the book -- the stories are engrossing and the ideas compelling. The book focused on the price individuals and humanity pay for scientific discovery. I loved the Grothendieck-Mochizuki arc for showing the price they individually paid with their pursuit, and the Fritz Haber story for the price the world paid for his work - he saved humanity from famine with the Haber-Bosch process AND killed millions with his poison gas. Reminds me of Dave Chappelle talking about what Bill Cosby meant to him ("he rapes but he saves")...

Think the broad idea across the book -- that the "innocent" generation of ideas can create unintended destruction, is something that Big Tech is grappling with today. Zuck created Facebook (and truly believes in its mission to connect people), and Facebook ended up being a disaster for politics and societies.

The mini-story at the end about how lemon trees die was poetic in what could happen with our obsessive capitalist pursuit of better and better technology: At the end of their life, “their fruits ripen all at once, whole limbs break off due to their excessive weight, and after a few weeks the ground is covered with rotting lemons. It is a strange sight, he said, to see such exuberance before death.”

title: How to Live: A Life of Montaigne in One Question and Twenty Attempts at an Answer
author: Sarah Bakewell
review:
I'm late to the party, but I glad I came. I loved the book, I loved the man, I loved Sarah's telling of his story. I think he puts into words many ideas I've flirted with over the past few years. As I was telling a friend, I think the best 21st century character that fits Montaigne's personality is Tyrion Lannister.

Things I loved (and will use)
- Epekho. I study at an institute that heavily incentivizes taking a stand on complex issues based on a 10 page summary, so I find the idea of wholeheartedly accepting a lack of a point of view refreshing. I don't understand a lot of things and genuinely do not have a point of view. And that's okay.

- Montaigne's drive to be empathetic and understand the world from another person's point of view is especially impressive given how alien that idea was at the time. Loved the story of his interacting with the Tupinambá and his relationship with his cat.

- Read Widely and Forget Most of What You Read: I complain often that my memory is getting worse. It's also unpredictable and unreliable - I forget my classmate's wife's name, but remember archaic facts about a movie I watched years ago. And I think that's okay too, I often re-discover ideas and narratives, and it's as much fun. As Montaigne said, clinging to one's opinion is the best example of stupidity.

- I think what was nicest was his willingness to be seen as unpredictable, inadequate and vulnerable. There's something attractive about people who are comfortable in their skin.

Also, whattey line: "If you press me to say why I loved him, I can say no more than because he is he and I was I."

title: A Gentleman in Moscow
author: Amor Towles
review:
Best novel I've read in a long time. Alexander Rostov is SUCH a quirky, interesting fictional character. Amor writes beautifully. Russian history always makes for a great read and reading about the Bolshevik revolution from the eyes of a Former Person stuck in the Metropol Hotel was also an interesting perspective. Some lines I'll keep reusing:

"After all, what can a first impression tell us about someone we’ve just met for a minute in the lobby of the hotel? For that matter, what can a first impression tell us about anyone? Why, no more than a chord can tell us about Beethoven or a brushstroke about Botticelli. *By their very nature, human beings are so capricious, so complex, so delightfully contradictory, that they deserve not only our consideration, but our reconsideration.*"

“It is the business of the times to change, Mr. Halecki. And it is the business of gentlemen to change with them.”

"For pomp is a tenacious force. And a wily one too. How humbly it bows its head as the emperor is dragged down the steps and tossed in the street. But then, having quietly bided its time, while helping the newly appointed leader on with his jacket, it compliments his appearance and suggests the wearing of a medal or two. Or, having served him at a formal dinner, it wonders aloud if a taller chair might not have been more fitting for a man with such responsibilities. The soldiers of the common man may toss the banners of the old regime on the victory pyre, but soon enough trumpets will blare and pomp will take its place at the side of the throne, having once again secured its dominion over history and kings"

title: Jugalbandi: The BJP Before Modi
author: Vinay Sitapati
review:
Took a few days to form thoughts about the book. Overall, thought it was not as revelatory as Half-Lion. Some parts were interesting to learn e.g., the story of the founding of the RSS and the Hindu Mahasabha, the competing interests and conflicts of the constellation of actors in the Sangh Parivar, opportunistic championing and disavowal of making a Hindu India based on the political climate in different eras. That said, Vinay Sitapati is probably the only attempting even-handed biographies of modern Indian politics, and I'm grateful he's working (sometimes amuses me that I've read biographies of unelected American bureaucrats but almost none of actual Indian politicians).

Think my biggest issue with the book was when it attempted to create a clean narrative around pivotal events like the Babri Masjid demolition and the Godhra riots -- his arguments on the actors' culpability (or lack thereof) felt too loose and unconvincing. And as a consequence, anyone who comes to this book already believing the BJP as an institution was either culpable or not culpable will leave exactly as they entered. Which, if my acquaintances' reactions are anything to go by, is exactly what is happening.

I think the scholarly contribution part at the end was helpful to read. And posed questions worth grappling with -- can one call the BJP fascist when it gains legitimacy from free and fair elections and parliamentary democracy?

In any case, think it'll be a few decades before an insightful biography of any of the characters in recent political history...there's a reason Robert Caro takes so long with his biographies!

title: My American Journey
author: Colin Powell
review:
Although I love well-written biographies and autobiographies, they are fairly difficult to come by. It is a tricky art to balance describing someone's value system and learnings while telling a compelling story (I thought Ed Catmull's Creativity Inc, for example, became too preachy at times, although it is a great book too). Colin Powell manages this well - My American Journey was one of the best autobiographies I have read in a while. Parts of it were so good that I broke one of my cardinal rules - I began marking out paragraphs I liked with a pencil.

I liked two specific parts about the book. One was Colin Powell's widely publicized views on leadership - he does a fantastic job of sharing how he sees leaderships and lessons he picked up along the way. Essentially, the stories behind his thirteen rules.

The other was his experience in Government - A democratically elected Government is a intriguing, confusing world. Powell says it well, "Democracy is give and take. People have to trade, change, deal retreat, bend, compromise, as they move from the ideal to the possible. To the uninitiated, the process can be messy, disappointing, even shocking." His experiences as the JCS and his year as a White House Fellow were my favourite parts of the book. His opinions of US Presidents were fascinating too (Reagan is an interesting character).

Admittedly, there were times when he sounded pompous, with paragraphs of American exceptionalism, and I do not agree with all his views (allowing gays to openly serve in the army etc.), but it was a very engaging read. Highly recommended.

title: Magisteria: The Entangled Histories of Science & Religion
author: Nicholas Spencer
review:
Glorious. V glad I read it.

- I like the framing themes: (1) Religion and Science have largely conflicted on either the question of “Is man / earth special?” or “who gets to decide?”, (2) early science was housed in religion pursuit as a way to understand how God created the natural world. Reading God Human Animal Machine right before was helpful to consider how these themes will never go away, especially with advents in AI. You very quickly hit the questions of what human consciousness is, is it specific to humans, can it be artificially created etc.

- Also liked seeing the many examples of how scientists reconciled their religiosity (and so many foundational thinkers were deeply religious!) with their science. It makes more sense to me how you can hold both these ideas in your head without conflict. The myth busting on many of these scientists was fun too - Einstein not being a practicing Jew, Newton’s religiosity etc.

- Also loved reading more about the three events that scaffolded the narrative - Galileo/Copernicus and the Church, Darwin/Huxley vs Wilberforce and the Scopes Monkey Trial

My only issue was that this book was entirely focused on western religious thought with a short foray on Islamic science and a bit on China. I’d love to understand how Hinduism interacts with Science

Think I’m less likely to disparage scientists who are overtly religious (eg ISRO scientists praying before the Moon lander mission), although I still need to wrap my head around superstitious beliefs and a transactional God vs something like Spinoza’s God.

title: Leonardo da Vinci
author: Walter Isaacson
review:
Thought it was okay. Realized I'm much more interested in professions that involve an understanding of the social sciences than the natural sciences, and that informs the types of biographies I enjoy. My experience with Montaigne (love) was in stark contrast to Leonardo. That said, decent biography of an amazing man.

Interesting things:

- Art has always required patronage of the rich. Maybe hedge fund managers are the Medicis of the 21st Century?
- It's interesting how Leonardo, Michelangelo and so many other Renaissance painters were gay. I'm guessing that if you don't conform to an established norm that's part of your identity, the only way you come to terms with it is if your worldview rejects the establishment - and, as a consequence, as an artist you break established norms in Art too?
- Childlike wonder is such a precious quality - I think sometimes that you require a certain sense of humility (or even insecurity) to retain wonder: you need to believe that there is still more to understand and more to learn. I miss the days where I was told "you will learn this in higher classes" - what is there to look forward to now?!
- Fell in love with Florence, again. Wonder what the equivalent of Florence in the 1500s is for this century? Maybe, New York / SF?
- Isaacson's prose is lucid, but unexciting. After reading a pithy ending to EVERY single chapter, you know what to expect. I didn't feel this in Jobs or The Innovators - wonder why.

title: One Friday in April: A Story of Suicide and Survival
author: Donald Antrim
review:
3 stars mainly because I wasn't in the right mindspace for this book. That said, it was haunting and vivid in how Donald Antrim describes the feeling of being suicidal. Think the sort of person who should read this book (and likely won't) is someone who's likely to say BS like "Suicide is a selfish act. People need to learn to be positive"

Quoting from the book: “As long as we see suicide as a rational act taken after rational deliberation, it will remain incomprehensible. Stigma, society’s unacknowledged violence toward the sick, will remain strong. But if we accept that the suicide is trying to survive, then we can begin to describe an illness. I believe that we must make this leap in our thinking. We must rule out myth and speculation. This letter, this report, this book, seeks a paradigm shift in our understanding of suicide in society. It finds neither will nor agency in suicide, only dying, and calls for a great commitment to the hospital, to our community and our health. What is the hospital, if not all of us? What is medicine, if not touch? Suicide must not be imagined as enigmatic; it isn’t poetry or philosophy. I have come to think of suicide as a natural history that may begin in trauma and abjection, or the withdrawal of touch, and that ends in death by one’s own hand. The purpose of suicide is death, not what we may think of as rage, revenge, or atonement for sin. To the extent that the suicide acts, it is but a falling away.”

title: The Rise and Fall of Nations: Forces of Change in the Post-Crisis World
author: Ruchir Sharma
review:
More than anything, a useful read. There are so many metrics floating around to assess an economy that it's useful to condense everything into a set of rules.

The book got slow at times with far too many numbers, I'm also realizing I'm much more attracted to concepts and theories than rules of thumb like "in 67% of cases where debt grew at 40% over 5 years, countries hit a crisis soon after". That said, I see how powerful these benchmarks are and I would pay good money to see his backup excel.

What I liked
- Fundamentally, how projecting for a 5-10 year period is so starkly different from projecting for a 20-30 year period. The book is purely about the former
- Good versus bad billionaires an interesting metric to use. I'd rather have my billionaires be from tech and manufacturing than from oil and real estate.
- How a working population affects growth and interesting fixes like baby bonuses work / don't work
- Geographic sweet spots. The geese model of South East Asia is interesting. I'd never thought about how little South Asian countries trade with each other

Some of the other rules (manufacturing led growth, cheap currency, low inflation) are standard and the rules about how a country needs a reformer leader and how media-hype typically picks up at the fag end of a growth phase seem trivial.

Net net - I'm going to keep Ruchir Sharma's list of rules on my Evernote for the next few years :)

title: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
author: Erik Larson
review:
Riveting story and wonderfully told. I was initially conflicted about reading about Churchill given his bigotry towards India and Indians but decided to give it a shot after being recommended the book by a friend I respect.

My biggest takeaway from the book (apart from the numerous vignettes of wartime life and the politics of war) was a reaffirmation of my belief that the world and people are far more complicated than simple narratives can contain. True, Churchill was bigoted. He was also an incredible wartime Prime Minister and arguably one of the biggest reasons the Nazis were defeated. He was a remarkable politician and gave courage and confidence to the world in a time of darkness and despair. Of course, it’s hard to balance out the goods and the bads but I’m not sure that’s even helpful - my bias is to see “fully” and acknowledge his whole contributions — good and bad — and have careful, restricted conversations on the specifics rather than trying to create a tidy, neat summary of his full life. In this particular story, he was a hero and Britain and the world should be grateful for him.

Anyway - I loved Beaverbrook - think I’m as much a fan of human drama as him. Think that’s the role I’d love to play in life - seek out drama for selfish pleasure but help the protagonists achieve happiness.

title: Roots: The Saga of an American Family
author: Alex Haley
review:
Long overdue but I'm glad I finally got around to Roots. I haven’t been this emotionally affected by a book in a while. For me, Roots was divided into 2 sections by this line, “The baby, six weeks old, was me.” Highly recommended, worth the 4 weeks the book took.

Found many things interesting

- Alex Haley discovering his past and his ability to go back 200 years in his family history. The part where he visits Juffure is fascinating, felt like an anachronism - the “laying on of the hands” ceremony was eerie.

- The travails of Kunta Kinte’s absorption into America, something I’ve been thinking about a lot. How do you adapt while retaining what makes you who you are? As a friend tells me often, "Be like Kunta."

- The gradual Americanization from Kunta to Kizzy to Chicken George to Tom. Useful metaphor is the wedding ceremony - they went from “jumping the broom” to a full-blown wedding at a chapel in 150 years.

- I liked the characterizations of some of the protagonists - especially Massa Lea and Chicken George. Love how Massa Lea vacillates between being an abusive rapist to a kind, father-like figure to Chicken George and how Chicken George is both a dedicated, ambitious professional and a terrible husband.

…and so much more.

title: Bad Blood: Secrets and Lies in a Silicon Valley Startup
author: John Carreyrou
review:
What I liked: I initially thought the numerous details of interactions between the famous board members (George Schultz, Jim Mattis, Rupert Murdoch et al) was irrelevant gossip. Towards the end though, seeing the extent the reputation of the board played on skeptics and the mental somersaults these people made to believe Holmes’ story was remarkable. To me, this story is one where gut and instinct doesn’t translate as rigor when you step outside your focus area. Schultz is a bureaucrat, Mattis is a military man, Murdoch is a news man - they know nothing about biotechnology. I like how TNC thinks about it - I dont understand public intellectuals, I can’t be one and don’t trust people who claim to be. The fact that senior technically competent folk (Dr. J, Robertson et al) also bought into the story makes it interesting also. They let their guard down because of their faith in Holmes.

I also thought Carreyrou stereotyped South Asians and used phrases I’m uncomfortable with. He says Sunny is Pakistani, and refers to him as Indian throughout. Get why he might believe that though, the company seems to be full of Indians and I’ve heard these stereotypes before (Indian men are brash, treat others like shit etc). Ah well.

title: Bewilderment
author: Richard Powers
review:
Not as powerful as Overstory, but still great. I don't think it made me see the world differently the way Overstory did, but raises profound questions

Discovered the book after Ezra Klein's recent interview with Powers which was glorious - I wonder if being more connected towards the natural world will solve the sort of capitalistic, career focused angst I so frequently find myself navigating...anyway, things I found interesting

- The relationship between Theo and Robin was beautiful, seeing parents try and understand children who think differently from them makes for such impactful stories -- was reminded me of a very specific instance of Far From the Tree by Andrew Solomon. Kids who think differently see the world differently, and we need (at least, I need) a better way to make sense of what differences we should prize versus try and "fix". As Powers says in one part, "Life itself is a spectrum disorder, where each of us vibrated at some unique frequency in the continuous rainbow"
- The alien worlds stories that Robin and Theo talk about is good Sci Fi material
- Needless to say, Powers's descriptions of Nature are as vivid and beautiful as you'd expect

Worth reading for sure

title: The Romanovs: 1613-1918
author: Simon Sebag Montefiore
review:
If Peter Jackson can make three movies with The Hobbit, the Romanovs deserve a 5-season TV series. Montefiore is a fantastic writer. Loved the book, although it was sometimes painfully long with far too much detail. Things I found interesting:

- Overall, liked how the 400 year history of the Romanovs serves as a cautionary tale for how Putin sees himself and Russia today. Putin's intervention in Syria restores Russia's Middle Eastern aspirations from Catherine the Great's time. Stalin compared his conquest of Berlin in 1945 with Alexander I's conquest of Paris 150 years before that. Putin's entourage call him the Tsar?!

- Thought Peter the Great, Catherine the Great, Alexander I and Alexander II were particularly impressive, although Nicholas II and his incompetence made for great reading.

- Loved how so many historical figures feature in the story: Rasputin (what a man!), von Bismarck, Napoleon, Leo Tolstoy, Dostoevsky etc.

- So much of the good the Romanovs did came from talented Ministers; the story is as much about them. Potemkin, Shuvalov, Witte, Stolypin etc.

Highly recommended, especially if you have a month with nothing to do.

title: Straight Talk on Trade: Ideas for a Sane World Economy
author: Dani Rodrik
review:
Don't think I appreciated this as much I should have. I'd read many of Rodrik's arguments before -- both in his and others' columns on PS -- and many of the nuances were lost on me, mainly because I'm not particularly knowledgable in trade economics.

Things I liked:
- Rodrik's trilemma: democracy, national sovereignty and globalisation are incompatible
- Reinforced the idea that trade doesn't distribute benefits equally - free trade will necessarily have some losers, and this will have implications on the politics of that country
- The difficulties of global governance on economic issues. I like his framework of what kinds of problems need some form of international coordination and what problems don't
- The idea that there isn't a single one-size-fits all institutional framework for all countries e.g., antitrust, central banking, market regulation etc.
- The idea that economists abstract complex ideas with numerous caveats into lossy, simplified versions that hide many of the frailties of the original idea. Coming from b-school, where 90 second soundbytes are the norms, this was a helpful defence of "it depends"

title: Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind
author: Yuval Noah Harari
review:
Okay, this was decent book. It was somewhat of a mash-up of Civilization, Ascent of Money (minus the glorification of the British empire) and a Dawkinsian book on evolution with an awkward philosophical ending on the meaning of happiness.

On some level, I think I'm done with generic "history of the world" books. The book felt...shallow in many chapters although I get his issue, he had 400 pages to cover 70,000 years.

Things I found interesting
- The 'Out of Africa' story of Homo Sapiens. Didn't realise our species is that destructive - the anecdote of the extinction of large mammals in Australia exactly when Sapiens landed there was interesting.
- The power of language in how Sapiens outlasted Neanderthals and Homo Erectus
- I like how he says Sapiens' development in the last 10,000 years has not been based on genetics. The Cognitive Revolution is where "history declared its independence from biology".
- The power of myths in building cohesive large groups of people. We need fiction to find common ground to bond with fellow humans.
- The polytheism -> monotheism -> dualism development of religion.

title: No Ordinary Time: Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt: The Home Front in World War II
author: Doris Kearns Goodwin
review:
Fun read - the 1930s was a fascinating time. Things I liked:

1 - Eleanor Roosevelt is AMAZING. What an intelligent, passionate woman - the Presidency was as much about her as it was about FDR
2 - Eleanor's and FDR's marriage was more of a strategic partnership - a warm-hearted, less devious version of Frank and Claire Underwood. It was curious how he loved and respected her but needed Lucy Mercer to play the traditional wife/lover role.
3 - The FDR-Stalin-Churchill dynamic was entertaining. Seeing how deferential Churchill was to FDR was fun (so sad that FDR backed off on giving India independence because it upset his friend). The FDR-Churchill contrast in speechwriting was interesting as well. Loved how FDR attempted to influence Stalin at Yalta - Ah, what I would give to be a fly on the wall in Yalta
4 - The way FDR rejigged the American economy to prepare for the War was impressive - it takes a strong President to convince

The book reinforced my view that a good politician needs to be a savvy negotiator in private and a convincing salesman in public. FDR and Eleanor were a special couple.

title: King Leopold's Ghost: A Story of Greed, Terror, and Heroism in Colonial Africa
author: Adam Hochschild
review:
Tragic story told so well. So surprised I hadn’t heard of this book until very recently. Everything from the tactics of how Leopold “acquired” the colony and the tactics of Casement, Morel and George Washington Williams to expose Belgium’s crimes to the broader reflections on the selective blindness of both colonialism (“Belgium saved the Congo from Arab slave traders…”) and its reformers (Britain’s colonies are somehow morally upright while Belgium is ruthless?) — such a powerful story, wonderfully told

The part about Lubambu’s assassination brings modern USA into the colonial conversation as well (surprise surprise). And the idea that the dictator who led Congo after Belgium left emulated Leopold’s regime and was similarly careless about the welfare of his people — shows that extractive authoritarian leadership comes in many forms. Useful template for what’s happening in the world today. Should read about how Congolese people today see this era in their history…

Williams, Morel and Casement. What inspiring men. And Casement inspiring Nehru brought this story closer to my heritage as well…

title: Finding the Mother Tree: Discovering the Wisdom of the Forest
author: Suzanne Simard
review:
Read this while being surrounded by trees. I loved her descriptions of the spaces she occupied and her almost spiritual reverence of trees. Reminded me of Richard Prum talking about birds - something special always seems to come of pursuing a topic you deeply deeply care about, even when it doesn’t neatly fit into the zeitgeist and prevailing norms of what is attractive and valuable. The science was fascinating. Also liked stories of what I’m realizing is a theme I love reading about — the politics of science and academia

That said, her narrative of how she went from her first puzzle (why did the newly planted Douglas Fir seedlings not grow?) to her eventual research and findings felt too programmed and very much a “hindsight is 20-20”. - it very well might be true but I’m just so skeptical of the idea that you can see the end from the very beginning of such large profound questions. The narrative felt a little too sure of itself and ended up not feeling “honest”.

Maybe I’m being harsh. I really wanted to love this book (after The Overstory and Merlin Sheldrake’s book etc).

title: Lincoln in the Bardo
author: George Saunders
review:
Decent read - Saunders writes beautifully, though it dragged on in the middle. Two things I especially liked:

1 - Saunders' exploration of Lincoln's sorrow was fascinating. The idea that his emotional state from his son's death was relevant (and useful?) to his being the President during the Civil War is interesting. I think Saunders brings out this emotion even better than Doris Goodwin does. Examples: "His mind was freshly inclined towards sorrow; toward the fact that the world was full of sorrow; that all were suffering; that one must try to remember that all were suffering" and "Oh, the pathos of it! ... I had seen, not so much the President of the United States, as the saddest man in the world"

2 - The book ended up being exploration of life and loss - something I wasn't expecting going in. The idea that you spend your afterlife compensating/atoning for your actions in life isn't particularly new, but some of Saunders' characters' stories were haunting and evocative. Grew very fond of Bevins and the Reverend.

title: American Prometheus: The Triumph and Tragedy of J. Robert Oppenheimer
author: Kai Bird
review:
Glorious biography. Covers two topics that I have always been intrigued by -- the politics of academia and the politics of scientists and academics. This reminded me of the JBS Haldane and Albert Hirschmann biographies. The book was definitely long (900 pages!), but loved most of the segues. Oppenheimer was a force of nature and a complicated, inspiring man.

Some thoughts:
- Loved reading about an era of physics that shaped my 12th grade curriculum - Heisenberg, Bohr, Dirac, Pauli, Einstein. What a time for Physics and Science! Wonder if the era of scientists being household names is behind us -- will we remember Jennifer Doudna or any of the ML thinkers the same way?
- I also look at Truman's decision to drop the atomic bomb on Hiroshima and Nagasaki much less approvingly. I admittedly didn't have a rigorous POV, but had internalized that it must have been done as a necessity. That was absolutely not the case and this was a violent, despicable act. Seeing

CANNOT wait for the movie!

title: Just Mercy
author: Bryan Stevenson
review:
So inspiring.

Being cocooned in an environment with people of means makes you forget that the world is an unequal place, and that most people don't have the access or privilege you have. This is the first time I've read about how means affects your ability to work with the legal system. It's tragic what some people have to go through because of societal and judicial prejudice.

Also, the idea of how we treat adolescents and children who commit is something I haven't thought about. Condemning a 13 year old (a work in profess human as Stevenson calls it) to lifetime imprisonment for a crime they committed is inhuman. Especially given that they had no agency in choosing the circumstances and the environment they were raised in.

I'd love to read about similar stories from India.

I'll never forget this: "You are better than the worst thing you've done". And must try to be a stone catcher, in whatever small way I can.

title: When Breath Becomes Air
author: Paul Kalanithi
review:
Sad, beautiful book. Paul Kalanathi writes so well - yet another talented doctor-writer (after Atul Gawande and Siddhartha Mukherjee) - and seems like such a thoughtful, humble and introspective person.

Loved many of his points of view - how physicians are counsellors and not just problem solvers, how they regularly operate at the intersection of life and death and how that affects their view of life, the difference between a job and a calling. Every time I read one of their books on their work, I start evaluating how comparatively insignificant my chosen profession (management) is. Much respect for doctors.

Also, Kalanathi talking about his upbringing and education is yet another reminder that we have far too little literature and humanities in Indian education. This is similar I think to how Steve Jobs looked at his life (the power of straddling the worlds of the Arts and the Sciences). Alas, I wish I had read more growing up.

title: India Unbound: The Social and Economic Revolution from Independence to the Global Information Age
author: Gurcharan Das
review:
Re-read India Unbound after 8 years. Feels like meeting an old friend whom you remember having a deep connection with, but whom you no longer relate to.

As I've told many, many people since I first read the book - I first discovered Government and Policy with India Unbound, a few months before I joined college. Reading the book was pivotal to many of my personal and professional choices.

I feel differently about the book now. Many of the caricatures are flimsy, and many of the generalisations perpetuate weak stereotypes. The conceptual basis of the book is still useful though, although the context in which it was written was completely different (Das wrote this in 2000, a whole 16 years ago).

tl;dr Good book for a foreigner curious about India or a naive teenager curious about his country 2 decades ago. Not as relevant now.

title: From the Ruins of Empire: The Revolt Against the West and the Remaking of Asia
author: Pankaj Mishra
review:
Truly unique perspective, although it was somewhat a difficult book to get through. Continue to believe that so much of international relations today is a function of memories from hundreds of years. Things I loved:

- Japan's historical imperial desires, to be treated as an equal to Western powers
- China's deep-seated belief in its greatness (it's finally here!); in contrast with their belief that India is a defeated, lost country
- The tension between modernisation and traditions in Islam; the idea that millions of West Asians thought of Islam as their solution to failed Western modernisation; the idea that Islam missed modernization
- The West's long suppression of the East - liberalism is only for Europe, not for Asia. Didn't know about the Paris Peace Conference

title: Thomas Jefferson: The Art of Power
author: Jon Meacham
review:
Man, that was a long read. Prodigious book for how much research must have gone into it but think it’s hardly the best biography I’ve read. Feels like Meacham was half apologizing for Jefferson’s flaws with so many caveats. Think I learned more about the complicated history of America’s founding years and the facts of Jefferson’s life than about the nuances and arcs of human nature (which is mostly why I love biographies).

On Jefferson - fascinating figure, clearly saw ahead of his times and was wonderfully open minded and curious, probably why he was able to develop such long lasting ideas. Of course, except on the topic of slavery - the power of individuals to compartmentalise the personal and the politics always astounds. Poor Sally Hemings - I’d love to read her biography.

title: We Don't Know Ourselves: A Personal History of Modern Ireland
author: Fintan O'Toole
review:
FABULOUS book. Never thought I'd enjoy reading a history of a country that, frankly, I've never been to, and haven't taken particular interest in through other pursuits. He's a wonderful writer and I loved the structure of the book - personal memoir as the anchor to tell the story of modern Ireland

Will share snippets at some point, but the key idea he explores was fun - how a country that was basically governed by a conservative traditional Church (or Church-affiliated political parties like Fianna Fáil) transformed into a progressive modern economy. The Irish "unknown knowns" was an interesting thread

Some parts reminded me so much of India...a deeply conservative country with a dominant religion and the struggles from grappling with modernity.

title: The Passage of Power
author: Robert A. Caro
review:
Glorious glorious read. Loved the first three quarters of the book, everything from how LBJ got onto the ticket, the LBJ as VP years (what a fascinating time for the man), the Bobby-LBJ sparring, LBJ’s first 6 weeks after taking charge. Thought Caro rushed through Civil Rights bill (where was Richard Russell in that part?!) negotiations although I guess Master of the Senate showed those machinations and backroom deals for his previous civil rights bill as Senate Leader.

Caro brings out the complexity of LBJ again - as history shows, when his compassion and ambition pointed in the same direction, LBJ delivered. The years as VP and his unexpected rise to President shows how so much of life and careers are governed by events completely out of our control.

title: Slaughterhouse-Five
author: Kurt Vonnegut Jr.
review:
Decided to read this because I was starting to get embarrassed that I call myself a SciFi fan despite not having read anything by Kurt Vonnegut.

On the book. It feels odd commenting on a widely acclaimed novel; if I say I loved it, I feel I’m being conformist and if I say I didn’t, I feel contrarian. Anyway: I loved his style, especially his use of mini-vignettes to jump across storylines. It’s something Pachinko (the previous novel I read) does too - casual, elegant jumps from one plot line to another.

Also loved his gentle commentary on the hypocrisies of American life (e.g., Rosewater discussing how Trout hasn’t been outside America and then says “That’s the attractive thing about war. Absolutely everybody gets a little something”.

title: I Don't Want to Talk About It: Overcoming the Secret Legacy of Male Depression
author: Terrence Real
review:
Probably the most significant book I’ve read in months.

I think I see my mental health differently, especially some of the causes (having lived my entire formative life in a performance based self esteem driven culture) and effects (believing I have self worth only if I am playing the game well, the sort of self medicating coping mechanisms I’ve developed to deal with the emptiness I feel so often)

I think I also see other men and boys differently. I don’t think I fully realize the corrosive effect our patriarchal society has on how boys see themselves…think I have much more empathy for the foundations of more repellant forms of male behavior.

“If patriarchy silences girls’ voices, it also takes aim at boys’ hearts”

title: The Orange Balloon Dog: Bubbles, Turmoil and Avarice in the Contemporary Art Market
author: Don  Thompson
review:
Decent read, essentially a 101 on the Contemporary Art market. Things I️ found interesting

- The ways in which a good with no intrinsic value (like, say, bullion) with unique characteristics (unlike bullion) is priced. Makes sense that market makers (auctioneers, dealers), outsized players (famous collectors) and a few firms attempting to add transparency (Artsy et al) define prices at the high end of the market.
- Also cool that the industry isn’t regulated and the Courts have made interesting rulings. Such a Caveat Emptor market with such high buy-in’s that I’d never enter without an influencer advising

The author clearly is trying to market this as an Econ book on Art, but it‘s more informational and less conceptual.

title: The Secret Race: Inside the Hidden World of the Tour de France: Doping, Cover-ups, and Winning at All Costs
author: Tyler Hamilton
review:
Recommended by Peter Attia, fun read. Didn’t realize how elaborate doping was in competitive cycling and how…unavoidable it was to dope if you wanted to compete and win. Makes the ethical arguments much more complicated - rather, have much more empathy for the athletes who doped than I did before

The one person I do not have more empathy for is Lance Armstrong. An ambitious and ethically ambiguous “win at all costs” mentality is dangerous of course, but if you combine that with natural competence and the ability to persuade folks around you, that’s a real problem.

Also interesting that Lance became bigger than the sport and the architecture around the sport contorted to protect him, and hence themselves.

title: The Midnight Library
author: Matt Haig
review:
Wonderful wonderful read. And yet another example that fiction is often better positioned to help you see life differently compared to non fiction - I’ve spent the last two years trying to make sense of my emotions and thoughts (regrets, pontification on roads not taken, the endless road of “ifs”). I believe that the causes for my anxieties and ennui were not unique (which is true) and that philosophers and thinkers must have explored ideas surrounding this. I’ve read everything from Proust and Alain De Botton to Montaigne and Thoreau, but this book spoke to me much more compellingly.

Simple read, lovely story. Admittedly not deep, but that’s not why you should read this book.

title: The Better Angels of Our Nature: Why Violence Has Declined
author: Steven Pinker
review:
Only appropriate response after finishing the book: "ZOMG". One of the most memorable books I've ever read - I went back and re-read multiple chapters to make sure I would not forget anything. Alas, if only textbooks in college were as riveting.

Pinker uses violence as a lens to write two different books - a data-backed history of (violence in) the world and an overview of moral and political philosophy. I admittedly got bored in the data-backed section (although I realize its importance), but loved the other two parts.

I now feel the same way I felt when I first learned about Evolution ("Oh, the Universe makes so much more sense now"). Everyone should read this book.

title: I Could Not Be Hindu : The Story of a Dalit in the RSS
author: Bhanwar Meghwanshi
review:
Powerful and important story, and surprisingly well written for a translated book (generally find language awkward, esp in translations from Indian languages)

Vivid depiction of many of the central questions animating Indian caste politics since Ambedkar and Gandhi's days: Can the emancipation of Dalits even happen from within Hindu society? Does the Hindutva project necessarily need to end caste inequalities for it to succeed politically? If yes, can the RSS and the broader Sangh Parivar end/reduce caste bigotry at least in their organizations given how the rest of society has struggled?

Overall, curious to see if we will see a Dalit Sarsanghcalak in our lifetimes

title: White Mughals: Love and Betrayal in Eighteenth-Century India
author: William Dalrymple
review: The book appealed to me for two reasons. One, it was a beautiful, tragic love story - this could very well be the Pocahontas of Mughal India. Two, love how Dalrymple used the story as a conduit to explore 18th century India - everything from the vivid descriptions of life in 18th Century Hyderabad (it's unfortunate that I have never visited the city) to explorations of a range of significant characters in British Indian history (Lord Wellesley, Robert Clive, the Nizam of Hyderabad et al). And, of course, loved the section on Aristu Jah and Mir Alam - the machinations of ambitious, intelligent and powerful men make for great stories. Worth reading.

title: Love at Goon Park: Harry Harlow and the Science of Affection
author: Deborah Blum
review:
Amazing, amazing book. Biographies of academicians is this fun new genre I've stepped into. Seeing how a young person's interest becomes a topic of research, and how they work on traditional and arguably mundane topics in the early years, until they get "hooked" onto a particularly important question, whose premise is often against the whims of the establishment, and if they manage to win that war of ideas, a question whose answer becomes their defining contribution to the field and beyond. It's pretty fertile territory for great stories - enough ideas, gossip and drama.

I've been quoting this book a bit too much...worth a read

title: Age of Ambition: Chasing Fortune, Truth, and Faith in the New China
author: Evan Osnos
review:
It was okay. Descriptions of dissidents and their struggle was evocative and insightful. The capitalist story felt very tradish and familiar. Maybe partly because this is almost a decade old and everyone talks about it + the themes are very similar to stories in India ("family moves from village to city for borderline blue-collar job in IT industry in Bangalore and wants their daughter to learn English and study engineering to become the next Bill Gates" - it's almost a trope now).

Was hoping to find an interesting hook into Chinese culture and history and contextualize present day themes. This wasn't that book for me.

title: The Gatekeepers: How the White House Chiefs of Staff Define Every Presidency
author: Chris Whipple
review:
Good read. Was particularly interested because of the job I'm currently in and past roles in Government.

The Chief of Staff role in Government is incredibly powerful and requires a very particular set of skills to be successful (corporate imitations are admittedly pale imitations lol). Was fun to see the range of Chiefs of Staff styles and how they made or broke presidencies -- from Jim Baker (Bush, Reagan) and Dick Cheney (Ford) to Haldeman (Nixon)

Separately - Jim Baker is such a legend, reminded me of The Man who Ran Washington, one of the best political biographies I've read.

title: The WEIRDest People in the World: How the West Became Psychologically Peculiar and Particularly Prosperous
author: Joseph Henrich
review:
Powerful ideas, and def one of the more interesting books I've read. 100% could have done with better editing -- it was hard to keep track of the narrative.

Should write a deeper reflection, but the themes around how Christianity and Protestantism influenced social and cultural life and amassed power (the Christian MFP - Marriage and Family Program) through taking positions on everything from monogamy, incest taboos etc. The variety of studies and experiments he describes were super interesting also.

Wish it was shorter. Preferred his podcast episode with Tyler Cowen.

title: The Best Minds: A Story of Friendship, Madness, and the Tragedy of Good Intentions
author: Jonathan Rosen
review:
Great read, moving story and well told. It did feel like many different themes / books wrapped into one and got a bit confusing.

At least three I noticed:
- exploring our conception of mental health and illness ala Rachel Aviv’s recent book
- Also a fabulous memoir reminiscent of Hua Hsu’s recent book
- and at times felt like a story of the times like Fintan O’Toole’s fantastic history of modern Ireland, but anchored on his individual upbringing

That said, worth reading for anyone trying to develop a position on how we conceptualize mental health

title: Jerusalem: The Biography
author: Simon Sebag Montefiore
review:
Learned tons, well written, and Jerusalem sounds like an incredible city but far too long for me (especially for someone who hasn’t been to the city, isn’t Jewish/Christian and isn’t obsessed with the Mamluks or something like that). Wish it was less a collection of factual vignettes and more a story about what the city is and where it came from.

I like this line someone said recently: There are authors who know a fact and are so happy that they’re insistent that you absolutely must know it too. Imagine that, but 500x

(Enjoyed the Romanovs more)

title: Winners Take All: The Elite Charade of Changing the World
author: Anand Giridharadas
review:
Worth reading once maybe. Often has fair critiques of how elite institutions try solving problems. But not enough depth to warrant being an entire book, should have been a long form New Yorker article. It also started seeming like a Thomas Friedman (the irony!) book with all these anecdotes of panel discussions intended to be revealing but just end up seeming like weak caricatures

EDIT on 11/28/19: Adding a star because realizing that this POV may in fact be atypical and unusual in elite public/private/social circles. Worth reading for that alone

title: Scale: The Universal Laws of Growth, Innovation, Sustainability, and the Pace of Life in Organisms, Cities, Economies, and Companies
author: Geoffrey B. West
review:
Great book - generally have grown wary of public intellectual type people using methods they're comfortable with to try and say things about adjacent/unrelated fields. This one feels like an exception - I think partly he seems fairly self-reflective and partly because he engages with prominent thinkers in the field he's trying to contribute to.

Found the biology stuff less interesting than the social science sections (man, I love cities - this gave me language and principles as to _why_ cities are incredible for the things I value).

title: A Little Life
author: Hanya Yanagihara
review:
Truly loved this. I think Hanya's ability to vividly describe the emotions and rationale of otherwise mundane familiar interactions truly made this a memorable read. Loved the exploration of the lines (or lack thereof) between friendships and romance, friendships and family, and the impact of your childhood on your adult persona.

Towards the end, I thought the book dragged a little bit with Jude's story - it's almost as if I was watching the character get beaten down again, and again, and again. Small issue, though - loved the book.

title: The Lincoln Highway
author: Amor Towles
review:
Man, this book got me hooked. Felt so invested in all the characters in such different ways (Billy and Woolly were my favs). Many of the plot threads felt so fantastical and so vivid - I was transported, this should become a Wes Anderson movie

I absolutely love Amor Towles - it's pretty cool how he casually drops little vignettes of wisdom from each of his characters in a way that feels so natural and profound at the same time (e.g., Sarah talking about how the excesses of our virtues bring people as much misery as their vices)

title: The World As It Is: Inside the Obama White House
author: Ben Rhodes
review:
Man I really miss the Obama years (despite its flaws). Have read about many of these encounters before - Gitmo, Cuba, Iran, but was a nicely told story. The Vatican angle to the Cuba negotiations was new - foreign policy is fascinating but I have very little intuition for it.

3 stars because great memoirs and biographies elevate the personal into something broader - in this case, a statement about political life, the trade offs in governing etc. This book didn’t do that despite Ben Rhodes probably having such perspectives.

title: Why Fish Don’t Exist: A Story of Loss, Love, and the Hidden Order of Life
author: Lulu Miller
review:
What a lovely, quirky, charming book. I bought it after a recommendation from the cashier at McNally Jackson - and truly didn’t expect the direction the book would end up taking.

I got a tattoo for my 30th birthday that says “Epekho”, roughly translating to “withhold judgment” with the intention to remind myself that there is are often two compelling sides to any story and many facts I do not yet know. To me, this book takes that idea and births something profound. If fish don’t exist, what else could be true?

title: Team of Rivals: The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln
author: Doris Kearns Goodwin
review:
This is likely the first time I've read about someone whose greatest gift was magnanimity. You read about great men and their dedication, passion and intellect, but it's fascinating to see the power of the ability to unconditionally forgive and rise above pettiness. tl;dr - Finally understand why Lincoln was such a stud macha.

Also - amusing to read about Lincoln and the founding of the Party that abolished slavery exactly when, 150 years later, it is being recast in the name of Donald Trump.

title: The Topeka School
author: Ben Lerner
review:
Read this on a 10 hour flight.

Powerful style, lucid prose and very lyrical. The main themes of the idea weren't particularly new (understanding white male angst in the US), but the style, structure and the channels he uses in representing the themes were pretty cool e.g., spreading in debating, how we co-opt and appropriate language, the complexities of therapy, mental health themes. The parts with Adam as narrator was a great coming of age story too...

title: Sea of Tranquility
author: Emily St. John Mandel
review:
She’s a wonderful writer and some of the scenes were memorable and touching, but thought the plot itself was pretty standard. Maybe I didn’t get it - I usually get somewhat befuddled by time travel plots.

I did love how science fiction wasn’t core to the story but in the background, it’s a nice touch, quite different from most books I’ve encountered in the broader speculative / science fiction genre.

Still want to give her other books a shot

title: Lonesome Dove (Lonesome Dove, #1)
author: Larry McMurtry
review:
Best novel I’ve read in a long time. Can’t remember when I last stayed up till 3am because of how riveting the plot was. I’ve never been interested in Westerns but gave this a chance because of how highly people spoke of it - and glad I did. Characters are rich and deep

Gus is a legendary character, as was Clara, Gus and Call’s friendship was moving, Call <> Newt’s plot was tough to read, the Gus <> Clara <> Lorena plot was great.

title: In the Light of What We Know
author: Zia Haider Rahman
review: The characters were okay, nothing special. And the topic itself was interesting. What was really good though was the author’s points of view and musings on people, geopolitics and history. Feels fairly laboured that it’s all channeled through one character but the ideas themselves were interesting. It’s the sort of novel that you’d go “oh! Wow” every few pages but you won’t grow more invested in the story itself. It’s a novel of ideas

title: A Promised Land
author: Barack Obama
review: He's a wonderful writer and this was a fun read. That said, sometimes felt like it was an Aaron Sorkin TV show ("I put my hands around Axe's shoulder and said, "this is why we do the hard work""!?) - reaffirms my view that current/recent politician autobiographies aren't that insightful, it's too close for truly insightful ideas to start being visible and the author has an incentive to correct and refine their public personas.

title: Burn Rate: Launching a Startup and Losing My Mind
author: Andy  Dunn
review:
Important book, and beautifully written (especially for a business book which are pretty meh in literary style).

More people need to talk about mental health in the corporate world - and it has to come from folks talking about it in their time working their way up the ladder (as opposed to a Fortune 100 CEO talking about their mental health practices today).

Inspiring, raw and vivid. Highly recommend.

title: The Three-Body Problem (Remembrance of Earth’s Past, #1)
author: Liu Cixin
review: Loved it. Thought Liu Cixin's description of Science Fiction at the end: "I feel that the greatest appeal of science fiction is the creation of numerous imaginary worlds outside of reality...the greatest and most beautiful stories were not sung by wandering bards or written by playwrights and novelists, but told by science...Only, these wonderful stories are locked in cold equations that most do not know how to read."

title: A Swim in a Pond in the Rain: In Which Four Russians Give a Master Class on Writing, Reading, and Life
author: George Saunders
review:
Incredible book. It’s actually 3 books in one — 7 great Russian short stories, Saunders’s reflections on the creative process in writing fiction, and Saunders’s meditations on the Big questions of life and living. So profound and so entertaining

There’s something special about this book, will keep coming back to it. I liked it so much I bought the book for posterity after borrowing it from the library

title: The Biggest Bluff: How I Learned to Pay Attention, Master Myself, and Win
author: Maria Konnikova
review: Came across Maria Konnikova on a bunch of podcasts and heard about the book. Loved it. What a captivating personal story and such a thoughtful writer. A lot of the Poker insights were generic and fun to read, especially given my current obsession with chess (a game that requires a very different skillset). Some of it felt not as interesting - I think it could have been a longform essay and been as insightful.

title: Entangled Life: How Fungi Make Our Worlds, Change Our Minds & Shape Our Futures
author: Merlin Sheldrake
review:
Amazing amazing read. What a story, everything from mycorrizhal fungi to lichens. Think after this and The Overstory, I’m starting to see forests less as aggregations of inanimate entities but more as a group of living beings that “collaborate”. Also, relates to themes of why our proclivity to form rigid categories of the world might often be flawed from Why Fish Don’t Exist

Must learn more

title: The City We Became (Great Cities, #1)
author: N.K. Jemisin
review: Was fun reading this while in Brooklyn. Liked it less than the Broken Earth trilogy, couldn’t fully wrap my head around how exactly the protagonists used their powers and what exactly the Enemy was. Ofc, loved that there were so many minority and queer characters - so unusual and so refreshing - but thought the progressive liberal v close minded conservative archetyping felt too rough and low res.
